questions.text: Which of the following drugs has best shown to reduce cardiovascular death in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction ?
questions.solution: Although half of all HF occurs among patients with normal LVEF, often with diastolic dysfunction, the only therapy shown to reduce cardiovascular death or HF hospitalization in this population is SGLT-2 inhibitors, specifically dapagliflozin or empagliflozin. The mainstays of treating HF with preserved EF are SGLT-2 inhibitors and diuretic therapy for fluid overload.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for treating symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage that develops within 24 hours of receiving IV recombinant tissue plasminogen activator?
All the following conditions can result in hyperkalemia except ?
questions.solution: Magnesium depletion has inhibitory effects on muscle Na+/K+-ATPase activity, reducing influx into muscle cells and causing a secondary kaliuresis. In addition, magnesium depletion causes exaggerated K+ secretion by the distal nephron; this effect is attributed to a reduct ion in the magnesium- dependent, intracellular block of K+ efflux through the secretory K+ channel of principal cells. In consequence, hypomagnesemic patients are clinically refractory to K+ replacement in the absence of Mg2+ repletion.

questions.text: Which of the following CSF levels may be elevated in patients with CJD ?
questions.solution:
CSF in CJD

CSF is nearly always normal but may show protein elevation and, rarely, mild pleocytosis. Although the stress protein 14-3-3 is elevated in the CSF of some patients with CJD, similar elevations of 14-3-3 are found in patients with other disorders; thus this elevation is not specific. Similarly, elevations of CSF neuron-specific enolase and tau occur in CJD but lack specificity for diagnosis.

choices.text: Start combination of aspirin and clopidogrel
Start dabigatran 150 mg 2 times a day

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman with hypertension is found incidentally to have atrial fibrillation. She has chronic kidney disease with a creatinine value of 1.8 mg/dL. What is the next best step in her treatment?
questions.solution: Warfarin for a goal INR of 2.0 to 3.0. Anticoagulation is war- ranted given the patient's CHA₂DS₂-VASc (congestive heart failure, hypertension, age ≥65 years, diabetes mellitus, previous stroke or transient ischemic attack, vascular disease, age ≥75 years, and female sex) score of 3 (age, sex, and hypertension). Dabigatran would require dose reduction given her creatinine clearance. Warfarin is the best of the listed options.

questions.text:
The following statements are true regarding 'Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young':
1. Inherited as autosomal dominant trait
2. No features of insulin resistance in majority
3. Low risk of Diabetic ketoacidosis
4. Insulin therapy is never required
questions.solution:
MODY

  • Inherited in autosomal dominant fashion
  • Strong family history (2 or 3 generation)
  • Young onset of Diabetes
  • Majority are non-obese without features of insulin resistance
  • Low risk of DKA
  • Though sulfonyl urea is the main stay of treatment, insulin therapy may be required in certain variants of MODY / long standing disease in commoner types
  • Serum insulin and C-peptide levels are low in MODY but is not as low as in Type 1 DM

choices.text: Increase the dose of mesalamine to 4.8 g per day

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with ulcerative colitis, well controlled on mesalamine 2.4 g daily, reports a 5-month history of back and buttock pain and stiffness that improves with activity but is beginning to interfere with daily activities. She has taken nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs over the counter for 2 weeks and had inadequate relief. Colonoscopy shows quiescent panulcerative colitis. Lumbosacral MRI shows sacroiliitis. What is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution: The objective of this question is to recognize inflammatory arthritis as an extraintestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease and determine the approach to its management. Large-joint pauciarticular arthritis (knee, hip) activity often parallels luminal inflammatory bowel disease activity. Axial inflammatory arthritis, such as sacroiliitis and ankylosing spondylitis, will not parallel bowel disease activity, will not respond well to disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs; eg, sulfasalazine and methotrexate), and will frequently require anti-TNFα therapy (eg, Infliximab). The dose of mesalamine should not be increased because the patient has axial arthritis and her ulcerative colitis is under good control, both symptomatically and at mucosal assessment by colonoscopy. DMARDs may be used for small-joint peripheral arthritis, which may respond well; caution should be used when prescribing methotrexate to women of childbearing age (pregnancy category X)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with velvety hyperpigmentation around her neck. She has similar changes in the axillae. What is the most likely associated condition?
questions.solution: This patient has acanthosis nigricans, which are velvety brownish plaques that most commonly occur in intertriginous areas (neck, axillae, and inguinal folds). The most commonly associated conditions are entities with insulin resistance, including diabetes mellitus, obesity, and polycystic ovarian syndrome. Rarely, acanthosis nigricans can be paraneoplastic and develop as a sign of internal malignancy. This should be considered in atypical settings such as a nonobese patient with rapid progression of acanthosis nigricans or involvement in atypical locations. In the early stage of HIV infection, cutaneous manifestations include genital warts, genital herpes, psoriasis, seborrheic dermatitis, xerosis, and pruritic papular eruption and not acanthosis nigricans. Mitral valve prolapse can be seen in patients with pseudoxanthoma elasticum, with pebbly yellowish texture along the neck line.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male smoker presents to the medicine clinic with increasing shortness of breath and decreased exercise tolerance. A CXR reveals bilateral lower lobe emphysema. A HRCT of the chest shows parenchymal destruction and bronchial wall thickening, predominantly at the lung bases. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency often presents in the 4th decade of life. The most common type of severe deficiency occurs in individuals who are homozygous for the Z-type protein (PIZZ). The emphysema has a lower lobe predominance and bullae are present in a third of cases. Bronchial wall thickening and dilatation may sometimes also be present

questions.text: A 60-year-old hypertensive man presents to the emergency department complaining of acute headache on the left and is found to have ipsilateral Horner's syndrome. His ECG shows a sinus tachycardia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Patients presenting with an acutely painful Horner's syndrome should be considered to have an internal carotid artery dissection. Carotid artery dissection causes a post ganglionic interruption of the sympathetic pathway and may be assessed with MRI of the head with contrast, and MR or CT angiography of the head and neck.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common indication for immunoglobulin therapy?
questions.solution: The first-line treatment of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is plasma exchange. Immunoglobulin therapy is not a recognised treatment for this condition

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents with increasing breathlessness over 1 month and has a large mediastinal mass on Chest X-ray. What is the most likely underlying haematological pathology?
questions.solution: In Myeloma, patients present with hypercalcaemia, renal impairment, anaemia, bony disease and/ or symptoms of hyperviscosity (headache, retinal haemorrhages, shortness of breath). AML patients may present with symptomatic anaemia, infection, constitutional symptoms of fevers, weight loss and night sweats, and/or specific features of different types of AML (e.g. M3 can be associated with DIC and present with haemorrhage; M4 and M5 are associated with gum hypertrophy). Patients with Hodgkin's lymphoma are usually between the ages of 15-30 years and may present with B symptoms (including drenching night sweats and weight loss), symptoms of bone marrow failure (including bruising/bleeding secondary to thrombocytopenia, lethargy and shortness of breath secondary to anaemia, and recurrent infections secondary to leucopaenia), and/or a cervical mass or symptoms from local effect from a mediastinal mass. Sickle cell disease is a haemoglobinopathy with symptomatic vaso-occlusive crises and chronic haemolysis.

choices.text: Infective endocarditis of the mitral valve

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 6-week history of weight loss, fever and muscle aches. On physical examination she has a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex and an echocardiogram reveals a mobile, well-circumscribed mass arising in the left atrium, from the atrial septum. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution: Systemic symptoms are consistent with atrial myxoma and with infective endocarditis. The diagnosis is clinched by a combination of the specific clinical findings of mitral valve obstruction (mid diastolic murmur) and a well-circumscribed mass that arises not from the mitral valve but from the left atrium and the inter-atrial septum. This is typical (80% of myxomas) of the location of a myxoma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents after having noticed that his urine is dark red in colour. He reports a 2-day history of sore throat, fever and muscle pains. His blood pressure is 160/88 mmHg, urine dipstick shows 3+ blood, 2+ protein. Blood tests show a serum urea level of 80 mg%, creatinine 2.2 mg% . He undergoes a renal biopsy and there are no proliferative lesions in the glomeruli. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: This 'syn-pharyngitic' presentation is typical for IgA nephropathy. No specific features are given that would be suggestive of the alternative diagnoses. The lack of proliferative lesions argues against post-infectious GN, which remains one of the leading causes of acute GN.

questions.text: The neuroleptic malignant syndrome toxidrome is characterised by:
questions.solution: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome presents with fever, dysautonomia, muscle rigidity and delirium. Pupils are normal. Deep tendon reflexes shows hyporeflexia in NMS.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with features suggestive of right heart failure. His ECG shows complete heart block, with low-amplitude QRS complexes. His CXR shows cardiac enlargement with prominent vascular markings. Echocardiography shows showed left ventricular hypertrophy with severe biventricular impairment and massive biatrial dilatation. The myocardium has a speckled appearance. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Cardiac amyloidosis is usually part of a primary systemic amyloidosis (AL) and is caused by extracellular deposition of insoluble fibrils. It leads to arrhythmias and congestive heart failure. It produces restrictive cardiomyopathy. Echocardiography shows speckled appearance of myocardium.

questions.text: A 50 year old male, who is a known case of old Pulmonary tuberculosis presented with 3 months history of fever, copious foul smelling sputum and breathlessness. On examination, clubbing and bilateral coarse crepitations were present. Chest X-ray done is shown. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The clinical history along with the chest X-ray findings suggest a diagnosis of Bronchiectasis, which is a known complication of pulmonary tuberculosis.

The diagnosis usually is based on presentation with a persistent chronic cough and sputum production accompanied by consistent radiographic features. Although chest radiographs lack sensitivity, the presence of "tram tracks" indicating dilated airways is consistent with bronchiectasis. Chest CT is more specific for bronchiectasis and is the imaging modality of choice for confirming the diagnosis. CT findings include airway dilation (detected as parallel "tram tracks" or as the "signet-ring sign" - a cross-sectional area of the airway with a diameter at least 1.5 times that of the adjacent vessel), lack of bronchial tapering (including the presence of tubular structures within 1 cm from the pleural surface), bronchial wall thickening in dilated airways, inspissated secretions (e.g., the "tree-in-bud" pattern), or cysts emanating from the bronchial wall.

Lung abscess usually produces a cavitary lesion with air-fluid level. Pulmonary tuberculosis produces fluffy opacities predominantly in the upper lobes. Although cystic fibrosis can cause bronchiectasis, there is no previous history suggestive of this. Therefore, Bronchiectasis is the best answer here.

questions.text: Which of the following is the clinical picture following liquorice consumption ?
questions.solution:
Licorice ingestion produces Hypokalemic Metabolic Alkalosis similar to the Syndrome of Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess (SAME)

The glucocorticoid cortisol has equal affinity for the Mineralocorticoid Receptor to that of aldosterone, with resultant "mineralocorticoid-like" activity. However, cells in the aldosterone-sensitive distal nephron are protected from this "illicit" activation by the enzyme 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase-2 (11βHSD-2), which converts cortisol to cortisone; cortisone has minimal affinity for the MLR.

Recessive loss-of-function mutations in the 11βHSD-2 gene are thus associated with cortisol-dependent activation of the MLR and the syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME), encompassing hypertension, hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis, with suppressed Plasma Renin Activity and suppressed aldosterone. A similar syndrome is caused by biochemical inhibition of 11βHSD-2 by glycyrrhetinic/glycyrrhizinic acid and/or carbenoxolone. Glycyrrhizinic acid is a natural sweetener found in licorice root, typically encountered in licorice and its many guises or as a flavoring agent in tobacco and food products.

choices.text: MRI brain and spinal cord with contrast

questions.text: A 41 year old female presents with history of blurring of vision and diplopia. On examination, she is found to have optic neuritis and bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia. What is the next step in the diagnosis of the suspected underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution: Considering the given clinical scenario, a diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis is most likely and should be made as soon as possible for timely initiation of disease modifying therapy. MRI Brain and Spinal cord with contrast is the initial investigation to be done at this stage.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease presents with history of 3 exacerbations in the previous year and a COPD Assessment Test (CAT) score of 8. What is the most appropriate treatment?
